rename.from: SoftAssertionExtension does not show line numbers
rename.to: SoftAssertionsExtension does not show line numbers

body:
Thanks for reporting this @Sam-Kruglov!
We will look into this in the next few days
Hello, I would like to work on this issue if this issue is still open ☺️.

Hi @Sam-Kruglov 
Sorry for the bothering but I failed to reproduce the problems you mentioned above. When using the static method it still does not show the line number.
My test case is:
```java
package org.assertj.core.api.junit.jupiter;

import org.assertj.core.api.SoftAssertions;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.TestInstance;

class MyTest {
  @Test
  void bla() {
    SoftAssertions.assertSoftly(softly -> {
      softly.assertThat("a").isEqualTo("a");
      softly.assertThat("b").isEqualTo("a");
      softly.assertThat("c").isEqualTo("a");
      softly.assertThat("a").isEqualTo("a");
    });
  }
}
```
And the result is:
```

to be equal to:

but was not.

Actual   :"b"
<Click to see difference>

```

I use: 
assertj 3.18.1
junit 5.7.0
java version 11.0.8

Could you please provide your complete test case or more information about dependencies? Thanks a lot for your help!

@Lanninger08 hey, sorry, but I don't have the full code anymore. I can see one difference in this log I had in my post:
```
INFO: Using test instance lifecycle mode 'PER_CLASS' set via the 'junit.jupiter.testinstance.lifecycle.default' configuration parameter.
```
You can set with the `@TestInstance(PER_CLASS)` annotation on `MyTest` class. I doubt it'll make a difference though.

I might have had the `spring-boot-starter-test` on the classpath, you could try that too. 

Maybe your classpath isn't clean? Try creating a brand new project with only plain java, junit, and assertj.

Otherwise, I'm not sure why it's different.

issue.title: Fix NullPointerException in primitive double assertions.

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Fixes #2166. (Not me)

Fix SoftAssertionsExtension does not show line numbers

I notice that the problem is caused by the different types of collectors. Both tests invoke `assertionErrorsCollected()` method but only `AbstractSoftAssertions` has methods that add the line number while `DefaultAssertionErrorCollector` not. `AbstractSoftAssertions` extends `DefaultAssertionErrorCollector` so I think we could move the methods that add line number from `AbstractSoftAssertions` to `DefaultAssertionErrorCollector` to solve the problem. After modification the line number shows up and still pass all the existing test cases.

I wonder if it is a proper way to solve this problem or there is a better way to solve this problem? 

#### Check List:
* Fixes #2092 
* Unit tests : NA
* Javadoc with a code example (on API only) : NO

issue.title: Fix SoftAssertionsExtension does not show line numbers

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Check List:
* Fixes #2092 
* Unit tests : NA
* Javadoc with a code example (on API only) : NO

I notice that the problem is caused by the different types of collectors. Both tests invoke `assertionErrorsCollected()` method but only `AbstractSoftAssertions` has methods that add the line number while `DefaultAssertionErrorCollector` not. `AbstractSoftAssertions` extends `DefaultAssertionErrorCollector` so I think we could move the methods that add line number from `AbstractSoftAssertions` to `DefaultAssertionErrorCollector` to solve the problem. After modification the line number shows up and still pass all the existing test cases.

I wonder if it is a proper way to solve this problem or there is a better way to solve this problem?

body:
If I recall correctly, junit's assertAll does show stacktrace in some way, can't check right now. It's easier to see which isEqualTo the error is talking about if I have the line number of that asserthion. Specifying descriptions is a bother IMO.

In any case, thanks for your time

Ok, so if I understand correctly it would showing the first stack trace element to easily navigate to the failing assertion.
This should be possible as `AssertJMultipleFailuresError` has all the `AssertionError` at its disposal.

Yeah but in case I have this assertion in a method I call multiple times it wouldn't be quite enough but I guess it's a corner case. Could also try using the first element's package name to find other related lines

I'm not sure to see how  suing the first element's package name to find other related lines would solve that reliably, can you provide a concrete example of this case? 

If there is no good solution for it, we might simply stick with displaying the first line which will cover a vast majority of the cases.

We could display lines as long as they refer to the same class. But I’m not pushing if this proves to be difficult, haven’t given it much thought myself. Does the first line always refer to my test file and not some insides of the framework?

You can't reliably know the test class name from the stack trace, most of the time it would be `XxxTest` but if we go that way it will not work if I named my test class `XxxChecks`.

What we could do is to show the 3 first stack elements, hopefully that should be enough to cover 99% of the cases.
